course.subject: SUST
course.name: Sustainability Fundamentals
course.description: This course provides students with an interdisciplinary perspective in comprehending the challenging issues on human sustainability on the limited planet earth. It also provides an overarching framework covering economic development, individual lifestyle and policies to deal with global, regional and local emerging issues to provide students with a good foundation for their sustainability related majors and minors.

reviews.author: dawns

reviews.comment_content: The content is normal. quite interesting for someone who concerns about the environment.
reviews.comment_teaching: A lot of group discussion. A hell for introverts.
reviews.comment_grading: The professor has some problems with his brain. I said we should have more subsidies for certain things and he said there are already subsidies for it. I KNOW SO I SAID MORE. DOES HE NOT UNDERSTAND THE DIFFERENCE BETWEEN HAVE AND HAVE MORE? And he cannot read a simple graph. He should be studying primary school and learn how to read graphs again. Also, I copied some paragraphs from his notes and he said he don't know what I was talking about. Does that mean he doesn't understand his notes? I explained why the issue would happen in the first sentence of the paragraph and he asked me why the issue would happen in the last sentence of the paragraph. DOES HE HAVE GOLDFISH MEMORY? reviews.author: LIFEGOOD
reviews.title: a retarded course
reviews.comment_content:
easy contents, but ridiculously hard to get good grades
Hard work DOEST NOT pay off
reviews.comment_teaching:
9am lectures and 3 hours long.
Teaching assignment itself is already retarded. I mean, who the fuck will be paying attention?
There will be a lot of discussions, so need to be awake.

Teaching is sometimes too boring, and not straight to the point. Professor talks too much. Her teaching makes me wanna go sleep.
TA never answer email. Retarded Teaching staff.
reviews.comment_grading:
Ridiculous (Fucked up) grading.
Your final grade will largely depend on your midterm grade.
If you fuck up your midterm, you will fuck up your final letter grade.
For group work, the mean is high, with very low SD. The mean was 9/10 and the min and the high are 8.8 and 9.2 respectively. Then why the fuck bother to grade them? just change it to P/F.

We worked so hard for the group poster and presentation, but we got below mean. Hard work does not pay off for this course. Do not take this course if you want to aim for high grades. I find this course really retarded, and professor and TA are not helpful at all. A lot of group discussions, and Professor is also kind of retarded. There was a free-rider in my group as well, and she did not act anything about this. TA never answer my email. Retarded TA.

I assume there must be using ridiculous mark scheme when grading mid-term and posters. I will recommend you NOT to take this course, if you are a hard working person, as the grade will not reflect on how hard you work.

Also, I have never seen teaching staff as lazy as this one. They PROMISED to release mid-term grade at least 2 weeks after the midterm examination. However, can you guess when they release grade? Fucking at early JUNE. (At least 2 weeks after exam? wtf?, then why the fuck you promise?). Can you imagine receiving midterm grade AFTER the end of semester? I have no words to say. To professor or TA if you are reading this, you should do something about this in the future. Keep your words !
reviews.comment_workload:
Not very much work load, just group poster and many discussions.

I emphasize again. Hard work does not pay off. So if you have to take this course, then don't work hard. You will not get around mean marks anyway. Just try your best in midterms. The most retarded course I have ever took in UST. Retarded professor, retarded TA, and retarded course.

reviews.author: bj
reviews.title: Good grade course but syllabus and workload may be tough.
reviews.comment_content:
As this is a SCC-S&T course, I think this course is best for those who have a weak science background. The syllabus mainly surrounds existing environmental issues and possible solution to these pressing problems. Peeps who took LS in DSE and Geography in IB should find this course interesting.
Be aware that we have a three hour lecture weekly, so the content is quite lengthy. The midterm is tested on the first half of the syllabus, so essentially you only have to pay attention in class for the lectures up until the midterm.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. Lau is a really passionate and kind professor. He is really down to earth with his students, as he likes to begin our lectures by asking how we are doing individually.
Teaching wise, he has a very fluent Konglish accent which is clear. Despite his quality teaching, it is still very difficult to stay engaged in a three hour online lecture.
He also likes to incorporate fun and educational activities in our classes, which to some may seem annoying and childish. But personally, I think it's good because it allows me to take a break from the lecture.
As said, he is a very kind person and he would be happy to listen if you have any questions or feedback for him.
reviews.comment_grading:
Our grade is determined by our midterm, group assignments, group project and a reflection essay. The midterm was a bit difficult as we had to answer a few essay questions under limited time, but I think the difficulty is fair if you revised enough. The group assignment and project are also very important, so be sure to find yourself with group teammates.
My midterm and reflection essay were above mean, and I got A range at last.
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload may be heavy, depending on your teammates. After each lecture, we are given a group assignment to do which is usually due one or two days afterwards. Those assignments require research which may take up an hour or two of your day.
Aside from that, the final group project can also be quite intense, once again depending on your teammates. We had to propose a solution to solve a given country's probelms and we had to present it in form of a video. It was not an easy task, but it could be a lot worse if I had free-riding teammates.

reviews.author: Annana
reviews.title: Introduction to Sustainability
reviews.comment_content:
Part A (Weeks 1 to 5) –the main features of the challenge of sustainability will be covered, including the principal impacts of human activity on the global environment and the options for managing these challenges. Students’ understanding of the issues covered in Part A will be tested in a mid-term exam.

Part B (Weeks 6 to 12) –possible and preferred futures for human thriving within planetary boundaries will be explored.

reviews.author: Hongjj
reviews.title: DSE LS + Geog, and a hell for introvert
reviews.comment_content:
Typical liberal studies stuff together with some geography concept. You know, social, economy, and environment these kinds of stuff.

1. Introduction
2. Anthropogenic (human) impact on natural systems
3. Planetary boundaries and Earth systems
4. Human thriving within planetary boundaries
5. Policy approaches for sustainability

(1-5 is midterm material)

6. Sustainable development and sustainable communities
7. Energy futures
8. Futures for fresh water
9. Design for a circular economy
10. Sustainable consumption
11. Futures thinking
reviews.comment_teaching:
THIS COURSE IS A HELL FOR INTROVERT LIKE ME. IN-CLASS ACTIVITIES EVERY FREAKING LESSON AND THERE IS A NEED TO DISCUSS THEM WITH YOUR GROUPMATE AND DO PRESENTATION TO THE WHOLE CLASS AFTERWARDS.

The online learning is just making things way more awkward as no one will speak until the breakout room session is almost over.

I can't really comment on Laurence, I didn't listen to him at all when he is presenting lol. he just read out from the ppt. but I do feel his passion in sustainability and his trying his best to give as many feedback as possible.

TA Christine is so nice and helpful, trying her best to help students in need.
reviews.comment_grading:
Fair and transparent
35% midterm
15% group worksheet (do 4 count best 3)
15% group video
10% Peer Evaluation
15% reflection paper
10% participation

but seriously everyone got nearly the same score. I think the only way to get an A in the class is do well in midterm. since everyone got the same marks in all different grade component and the range is so small.

FYI mean for each:
midterm 24.5/35
group worksheet 4.7-4.8/5
group video + Peer evaluation 19.1/25
reflection paper 12.1/15
participation 7.4/10

everything above mean (1-2 marks), midterm 33/35. eventually got an A

midterm is easy as long as you have geography knowledge and LS thinking, put them together with some term taught in the ppt then will get full mark
reviews.comment_workload:
it is said in the syllabus that you have to read the powerpoint slides before going to lesson. I don't find the need to do so. every in-class activities is just common sense and making reasonable judgement. little to no ppt material is needed when doing those in-class activity.

I think the main workload comes from the group project. so after midterm you will be busier. in week 6-9 you have to finish a worksheet (which you find data and statistics and provide analysis and elaboration) with your group mate.

and in week 11 you have to submit a 10min video discussing the sustainability issues in your assigned country.

if your group have freeriders then sure you will have higher workload.

reviews.comment_teaching:
Lesson flow: 1hr lecture + 1.5hr activities
His lectures are rubbish, he just read through the slides word by word without adding any new things. All you need is read through the pre-lesson slides and you can get all you want.
The activities are interactive, but his instructions are often unclear, especially for the flow of group discussion and the following activities.
However, the TA Christine is very helpful and she is willing and able to answer all our requests clearly and comprehensively.
E for professor and A for TA.
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm exam: 35%
Mean: 24.5/35    Me: 32/35
Worksheets: 15% (Highest 3 out of 4)
Mean for all WS are above 4.5  Me: 4.9/5,4.9/5 and 4.6/5
Presentation and Peer Review: 25%
Mean: 19.1/25     Me: 20.25/25
Reflection paper: 15%
Mean: 12.1/15     Me: 12/15
Class attendance and participation: 10%
Mean: 7.4/10     Me: 7.3/10
Overall Mean: 77.4 (B)    Me: 85.95 (A-)
Since this is a course adopting absolute grading policy, getting mean score overall will get you a B.
B: >=76
B+: >=80
A-: >=84
A: >=88
reviews.comment_workload:
Midterm: Just revise days before and get a big picture of the first-half of the course, since all are short questions and they require your understanding of concepts and some recitations on definitions, you need to prepare. As this is the only assessment that has varied grading, do your best and you can secure a B+ or above.
Worksheets: Work with group members in the group project, the better you do, the more preparation you can get for your project.
Present and Peer: Just a 10-min video about sustainability issue and SDG goals in a country, easy to do if no free-riders in your group and you have done well in the worksheets
Reflection Paper: Just an 800-word essay explaining what you have learnt from the lectures. Probably spend you within an hour.
Class attendance and parti: 5% attendance and 5% participation, I don't know how it counts as lessons are conducted online.

reviews.comment_content:
Part 1:
L1: Introduction
L2: Anthropogenic impact on natural system
L3: Planetary boundary
L4: Human thriving
L5: Policy
L6: Sustainable development
---------------------------------------------
Part 2:

Contents in part 1 are included in the midterm exam.
Although there is no final exam for part 2, you still need to understand the concepts as they will be used in other assessments.
reviews.comment_teaching:
A 3-hour lecture every week, usually started by talking about ideas in different topics and in the later half of the lesson there would be some activities and games.

Lectures are very interactive and participation is needed.

Benjamin was able to deliver the ideas clearly with further explanation.

At the start of the semester, you will be invited to join the lesson even though you are still on the waitlist (around top 20, I was at 18 and still managed to enroll in it). If you are waitlisted, remember to attend the lectures so you would not miss out on the contents.
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm exam: 35%
    >30.25/35
Group project: 40%
    >3 worksheets out of 4 with highest mark would be calculated
    >4.75/5, 4.3/5, 4.3/5
    >Video presentation & peer review 21.5/25
Reflection paper: 15%
    >14/15
Class attendance and participation: 10%
    >8/10

Grade: A-
reviews.comment_workload:
For every lessons there would be reading material that on average is around 70 pages of powerpoint slides. It takes at least 1 hour to finish reviewing them and they are mostly the same as those to be discussed in lesson.

There are also additional sources that you can read if you are interested (I didnt do so).

For L6 to L9, there will be a worksheet every week to be finished together with your groupmates. They are usually handed in within 24 hours of the end of the lecture, and some time is provided near the end of the lesson for you to discuss with your groupmates.

These worksheets are in preparation for the final video project in which a random country would be assigned to your group and you will have to discuss the sustainability issues in said country. In L12 you will take turn to comment on 2 other groups' video as well as being asked a few questions by the instructors, so be prepared for that by remembering some related information that you are responsible for in the video.

reviews.author: VLi
reviews.title: Register if you want a B
reviews.comment_content: Mainly about learning to protect the environment. As a business student, it was only interesting to me was when the professor talked about how businesses can be conducted in a more sustainable manner. Real life examples are listed and some interactive and awkward exercises are conducted in class every once in a while. The content is broad, yet it sacrifices depth and it is very confusing for most students. Yet as this is a new course, it is conducted differently every semester, so please anticipate change when you register.
reviews.comment_teaching:
To be frank, it's really boring unless you're all about conserving the environment. The class is conducted in an awkward manner. Don't expect much from the class; learn more via pre-assigned materials every week before class if you really want to learn.
Every class is 3 hours and around 1.5 hours into the class you get a tea break; the professor puts out bowls of snacks and fruits for the class to eat, which after that half of the class leaves.
The teaching can really be improved.
Attached are a few of the slides for students to read before class, which everyweek there is a new set of slides to read on and be tested on.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading system is like communism; some people work very hard for this course, some just chill and both of these people get a B range score. As the professor said, this course is graded with the absolute grading system, not relative or curve-based. Don't expect too much even though you work very hard, because if the content of your assignment does not align with the professor's views, you won't get a high score. Please take note that professor David mole studied his BA in Economics in Cambridge UK, so don't take him lightly. The bright side is, he is very generous with giving out Bs.
reviews.comment_workload:
In comparison to the other courses in HKUST, this course has a rather light workload. Once in a while, there will be an important assignment; which for my course, it was 5 in-class quizzes (25%), 2 reflection papers (each paper requires about 800 words), a group project which only requires you to present in less than 2 minutes.
No attendance needed. Grading doesn't matter if you're active or not. No mid-terms, No finals. Just don't be too lazy and submit your assignments on time.

reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is so heavy.
Having group meeting for many times for the group work. HELL.
My group members are all responsible and have the effective division of labor already. BUT the workload is still too much, the team report 1/ 2 is already the length of the final report of other courses. Not to mention you need to design the poster and present.
Since Meike was having one lecture less due to public holiday, she changed our presentation to hand in video.

Need to prepare the midterm (all long questions about you views and need to explain). Typing answer on Canvas is torture. It is open book (online exam).
Many readings and they might be tested in the Quizzes.
The essay is asking your own reflection about what you have learnt in this course.

Participation: for zoom, I just typed in the chat box but for f2f, it is important to raise your hand and share your opinion, no matter it is right or wrong, just give some reasons and make it has logics is ok.

reviews.author: DawDawDaw
reviews.title: Only the Midterm Matters
reviews.comment_content: Lots of geography content, which the prof skimmed through. The content itself, except for some political geography, is pretty challenging if you haven't studied geography before.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The professor is energetic, but constantly spends lots of time playing in-class games with us. But it's not what I expect.

The lectures are too long, with some extroverts "bullshitting".

Don't expect you will learn some profound geography knowledge in this course.
reviews.comment_grading:
I got an A. (Midterm 28.5/30; time management matters, I failed to finish the whole exam.) Performing well in the midterm will be fine. The other assignments/projects don't really matter.

Go for this course if you performed well in DSE/IB geography. Study the PPTs and answer with geographic terms.
reviews.comment_workload:
Quite heavy.
Report & Poster & Presentation & In-class quizzes & Essay

reviews.comment_workload:
really depends on your teammates - theres diversity requirements on group forming but you get to choose your own teammates so its chill

i had some wonderful teammates and we split on how much to contribute in part of the project depending on our other commitments (some made 1st internal report, some 2nd. finals some people worked on presentation + some work on poster)

with that minimal workload

reviews.author: vtecf22c
reviews.title: Not as good as I expected, but useful for academic requirements
reviews.comment_content: Course content is generally positive and relevant to most of us. Teaches quite a lot about the sustainablity issues and various case studies, which is engaging. For me it's more like a geography class from high school, but the difference is that the course tries to sell you ideologies at times you might agree or disagree.
reviews.comment_teaching: The lectures were engaging and interactive. Was not boring at all. But I have to remind each of you reading, that keeping a critical mind is key, whether you agree or disagree with the agenda the course is picturing.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading was not good for myself, I worked hard for the assignments but the effort don't really pay off in the end. Not sure what they are looking for here actually, i got a C+ btw.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is not difficult but volume is huge. Group presentation and reports are required.

reviews.author: SmallPotato02
reviews.title: OK course
reviews.comment_content: This course is about the challenges the world is facing to have a sustainable life by doing projects for respective countries for different groups. The course includes the concepts of planetary boundaries and circular economy. The whole course is divided into two main parts and the midterm exam only covers the first part. The structure of the midterm is like DSE LS exam. Therefore, for students who are good at these short essay writings, it is not difficult to have good results. Also, as it is an open book exam, students only need to remember the concepts but not the exact terms because you can check it on your tablet. As for the project, it is about a study for a specific random country and generate a poster to present.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor's teaching style is quite interactive and she is a willing to answer questions. However, for the assignments of the projects which are mainly marked by the TAs, the grading structure is a little bit unclear.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is quite OK because for our group presentation, it is just normal performance while the midterm is just slightly above mean. It results into a B+.
reviews.comment_workload: For the workload, in the first half of the course, it is normal because the quizzes are not there yet. However, for the second half of the course, we are having weekly quizzes in class which requires you to revise the whole ppt even they are open book quizzes since the quiz time is just 5 / 15 minutes (Sorry I can't remember correctly). Also, for our session, it is from 9 - 12 pm. So keep this in mind before you assess the workload.

reviews.author: Terryboltzzz
reviews.comment_content:
Mid term content
1-Introduction
2-Anthropogenic impact on natural systems
3-Planetary Boundaries & Earth Systems
4-Human Thriving within planetary boundaries
5-Policy for Sustainability
6-Sustainable Development
Part B: After mid term

7-Energy Futures
8-Futures for Fresh Water
9-Circular Economy
10-Sustainable Consumption
11-Futures Thinking
12- Presentation

If you studied geo, it would be pretty easy to grasp the content cause there are some concepts you will have seen before. Some of the content is a bit common sense, a bit bsing/吹水 will do fine in the mid term.
reviews.comment_teaching: She teaches fine. She makes a 9am 3 hour lecture more bearable to endure through. She tries to use activities to try and deliver the content to make it easier to understand. Although some of the activities might not have a lot of connection towards the lecture itself and still have to do some self study at the end.
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm exam (25th Oct. 06:30 –08:30PM) 30%
6 long questions, just a bit of bsing and common sense

Mini Quizzes (3 out of 5 count towards grade) 15%
The difficulty of the quiz is not difficult and is also open book. However once you answered a question, you can't go back and you don't know how many answers for each question (each question can have more than 1 answer)

Group project* 35%
• Incl 15% poster presentation, 5% peer-review, 15% 2 interim reports; ** incl 3% peer review
-Do work and don't be a free rider and would secure ok grade

Written assignment 10% - Ａ reflection on the course

In-class engagement ** 10% - Do at least one answer one question the professor asks and it should be fine to secure a relative ok score. Fyi, I did this and I also dosed off during lectures, at the end I scored relatively high for this part

My grade:
Scored slightly above mean for project
At least 1 SD above for mid term
A range
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload before mid term is acceptable. Review the course material before the mid term like a day before should secure a decent grade. After mid term will have a quiz at the start of every lecture so recommend read the notes the night before.
Heaviest workload would be the group project, have to arrange out of class time to do work

reviews.author: gyy
reviews.comment_content: The course consists of two parts. The first part provides a brief overview of the impact of human activity (such as deforestation, overconsumption etc.) on the environment. The second part focuses on how people (government, businesses, individuals, engineers etc) should help tackle the climate and other environmental problems.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor is very kind, and encourages class discussion, and value everyone's opinion. The pace is great. There's a lot of class activities that will invoke a lot of discussions.
reviews.comment_grading:
The professor likes people who provide their opinion and answer his question so you must be proactive if you want to score high in class participation

There are 5 quizzes and only the best 3 is graded so no stress on the quizzes even if you screw some up

Mid-term Exam (30%)
Mini quizzes (15%)
Group project (35%)
     • Two Interim Report (15%)
     • Poster (15%)
     • Peer Review (5%)
Written Essay (10%)
Class attendance and participation (10%)
reviews.comment_workload: The detail about the project is released about a week before the deadline, so you have to work with your team members to divide the work equally and manage your time. Just find a good team and you should be fine.

reviews.title: Demanding but very well-organized course
reviews.comment_content:
Have a look at the attached syllabus.

This really is a blended-learning course, as you should expect to deal with concepts in sustainability, group activities in every lecture where you have to apply the concepts that have just been introduced, reading wordy ppts beforehand, doing a group project with 2 reports and 1 poster, and writing a final essay. Everything from the course just gives me the impression of a course very well organized by experienced professors and teachers.

I don't know if this is because participation points are counted, but my section has a lot of students who are extremely proactive in raising/answering questions in class. Prepared to be overwhelmed by them, or if you can, be one of them!
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Benjamin is willing to let students take the stage during the lectures. He always encourages us to raise our ideas, and he would give encouraging feedbacks to teams that volunteer to present their work to the class during group activities.
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm exam: 30%
Quizzes: 15% (best 3 out of 5 quizzes counted, 5% each)
Group project: 35% (report #1 5%, report #2 10%, poster 15%, peer review 5%)
Final essay: 10%
Participation (including attendance): 10%

Midterm exam: Books, notes and Internet allowed but the instructors are very strict in grading this exam, and there will be point deductions for even seemingly neglectable errors. Recommend to go through all the ppts one day before the exam so you know which ppt to look at and find the answers immediately when reading the questions.

Quizzes: 3 MCs in 5 min for each quiz. Wrong answers are penalized, so be careful when guessing. Will only be conducted weekly after the midterm exam. Do go through the ppts in advance since you can't read them all in 5 min.

Group project: Really depends on whether you have proactive members in your group who are willing to go to extreme lengths to make your group stand out.  My group was not outstanding but not bad so we received above average scores. Workload can be heavy, especially for the poster, which requires lots of group meetings as we have to collectively decide on the contents to be put on the poster. Recommended to contact students from previous years so you can see how their group products look like.

Essay: Not difficult, if you are really interested by this course, you can do this one with ease. Just remember to submit before deadline.

Participation: Also an exhausting component, since lots of students are always ready to raise their hands, which means you really have to stay awake throughout the class to capitalize on your chance when it comes.

My grades:
Midterm: 26.5 (mean 22.78)
Quizzes: 15 (mean must be high, around 13-14 I guess)
Report 1: 4.4 (mean 4.24)
Report 2: 9 (mean 8.8)
Poster: 12.33 (mean 11)
Peer review, essay, participation: not published
Grade: B+
reviews.comment_workload: Generally high, especially after the midterm when we have to study for weekly quizzes and at the same time do the group project in November, when all courses have deadlines. The group activities in every lecture can be really exhausting, and you don't want to come into a 3hr class haven't had any sleep the night before. But after all, it was a great course.

reviews.author: Damien
reviews.title: Easy course, but require quite a bit of talking/bullshitting
reviews.comment_content:
Part A
1-Introduction
2-Anthropogenic impact on natural systems
3-Planetary Boundaries & Earth Systems
4-Human Thriving within planetary boundaries
5-Policy for Sustainability
6-Sustainable Development
Part B(relating to sustainable development goals)
7-Energy Futures
8-Futures for Fresh Water
9-Circular Economy
10-Sustainable Consumption
11-Futures Thinking

Midterm only cover Part A.
Quizes only cover Part B(No Finals)
Overall the content is very easy, if you have learn general studies or geography, etc it would be a easy A course for you.
reviews.comment_teaching: Overall Meike, is a great teacher, she has quite low expectations imo,
reviews.comment_grading:
Assessment
Midterm exam (25th Oct. 06:30 –08:30PM) 30%
Mini Quizzes (3 out of 5 count towards grade) 15%
Group project* 35%
• Incl 15% poster presentation, 5% peer-review, 15% 2 interim reports; ** incl 3% peer review
Written assignment 10%
In-class engagement ** 10%
-If you raise your hand to contribute; you get points
-If you are actively participating during class activity; you get points
-Attendance/Not being late to class; also get you points
reviews.comment_workload:
There is no homework
Group project requires 2 reports, roughly 1500 words per group.
Group project is presented using a poster and 8 mins presentation.
Written assignment at the end of the course for reflection.

Additionally, quizzes are open book, and based on the required reading materials. So if you don't read it beforehand, you might struggle in the 5 min duration of the quiz.

reviews.author: YwkRic
reviews.title: decent option for SSC common core
reviews.comment_content: The content are honest-to-heart meaningful and interesting, especially certain parts of interactive games/learning on a scale never seen before.
reviews.comment_teaching: Teaching is fine. Since it was first time for the course to adopt online teaching mode, some elements(e.g. student responsiveness) are yet to be desired. As a result, the teaching took a toll.
reviews.comment_grading: the grading was just fine, I guess. As long as you are attentive during the group activities and completed the essay, presentation and tests accordingly you should be fine. However one thing to be noted is that since some of the time students are silent, the group activities remained silent at times.
reviews.comment_workload: it is fine, you only have to complete some sort of questionnaires/preparation from websites/news websites. starting from the middle of the course, each group has certain presentations/essays to be handed in while following up the progress each week.

reviews.author: Sam23
reviews.title: Good Prof Good Grades but come with a lot of work
reviews.comment_content: A lot of interesting sustainability issues discussed in the course, which is very fascinating for students from other schools. Topics like System Thinking, “Whole is greater than sum of the parts “ , UNSDG, planetary boundaries, circular economy, etc, would be very relevant to the rising trends of ESG and sustainability in many companies.
reviews.comment_teaching: Arthur is really passionate and devoted in teaching the course where he spent extensive amount of time to prepare for the materials and fun games to engage the students. Him and the TA team also provided plenty of support throughout the course to help us accomplish the tasks.
reviews.comment_grading:
Mid-term Exam (35%)
A mid-term exam, common to all sections, covering Part A (Lecture 1-6)

Mini quizzes (15%)
Starting from Part B, a short quiz will be conducted for each class to test basic understanding of the concepts covered in the required reading. Each quiz will account for 5pt. The best three out of five quizzes will count towards the final grade.

Group project (25%)
Students will work in groups to research and identify the key sustainability challenges and provide possible solutions for a selected region. Additional details with instructions will be made available in the coming weeks.

Interim Report (10%)
Twointerimreportseachaccountingfor5ptarerequiredtoreportontheprogressof
the project work.

Poster (10%)
o A poster, detailing the findings in a concise manner, should be presented in the last lecture.
o During the poster presentation, each group will have individual Q&A session with instructors. You will also receive questions and feedbacks from your peers.

Peer Review (5%)
Comments will be mandatory and will be reviewed by the instructional team to ensure fairness in evaluation.

Written Essay (15%)
There will be one short (800-word) written assignment, due at the end of the Term to provide you with an opportunity to demonstrate your overall understanding of the issues covered in the course.

Class attendance and participation (10%)
   
The course includes many in-class activities and discussions to facilitate students’ learning. Class participation is therefore essential not only to promote your own learning, but contribute significantly to the learning experiences of others in the class.

The grading is quite good, I got an A in the end. I got above mean for almost everything and 1-2 sd higher than mean for the midterm.
reviews.comment_workload:
A LOT of work

There are 2 midterms for the first half of the syllabus. Afterwards, you get quizzes every single week and the best 3 out of 5 would be used as your final score.

For the group presentation, you have to submit assignments every other week, which is quite hectic. On top of that, you have to give a final presentation of a sustainability poster that you and your group compiled together as a whole.

reviews.author: lorleng
reviews.comment_content:
It starts off with very general things about the environment and then prof starts to teach rather detailed but easy-to-follow concepts and also teaches you how to apply.

1. Introduction
2. Anthropogenic (human) impact on natural systems
3. Planetary boundaries and Earth systems
4. Human thriving within planetary boundaries
5. Policy approaches for sustainability
6. Sustainable development and sustainable communities
7. Energy futures
8. Futures for freshwater
9. Design for a circular economy
10. Sustainable consumption
11. Futures thinking
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof kind of reads off the slides but he speaks fairly well and he answers questions during the class. Pretty chill dude, I enjoyed being taught by him.
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm exam: 35%
Group project: 40%
Reflection paper: 15%
Class attendance and participation: 10%

It's pretty easy to score if you put in a decent amount of effort.
reviews.comment_workload:
The interim reports and projects are related, you really need good groupmates to get it done well because it involves a fair bit of reading and understanding.

Highly encourage you to be active in class, ask questions and present mini-group discussions.

reviews.author: g
reviews.title: Big workload but you can get good grade if you put effort
reviews.comment_content:
If you are interested in sustainability issues, the content of the course can give you an idea of the fundamentals. The topics are also related  to our everyday life.
Class activities for attendance taking every lesson
Required to turn on camera
reviews.comment_teaching: There are discussions during every lesson. Did some interactive class activities (e.g. calculate your energy consumption and your household consumption), and played some online board games. Overall good teaching but could be boring sometimes.
reviews.comment_grading:
Only spoke up a few times in the beginning of the semester for participation, show up every lesson
Put more effort into the group project if you want to get good grades
reviews.comment_workload:
Big workload for cc but still manageable.
Quizzes every week for the second half of the semester (but the answers are in the ppt slides so should be able to get full mark if you read the ppt beforehand)
Two interim reports, final poster and presentation for the group project, should be manageable if you found good teammates, better find friends to reg this course tgt
Reflective essay at the end of the semester

reviews.author: Thomas Leung
reviews.title: Heavy workload course
reviews.comment_content:
1. Introduction
2. Anthropogenic impact on natural systems
3. Planetary boundaries and Earth systems
4. Human thriving within planetary boundaries
5. Policy approaches for sustainability
6. Sustainable development and sustainable communities
7. Impact of Covid on SDG
8. Energy futures
9. Futures for fresh water
10. Design for a circular economy
11. Sustainable consumption
12. Futures thinking

Content mostly revolves around how human activities impact on different aspects of sustainability, as well as introduce different perspectives of the problem and solution. Relatively simple ideas and concepts, no need to memorize a lot of content as well.
reviews.comment_teaching: Strong accent and poor connection, almost every lesson have connection problems. He does try to make every lesson interactive and fun, hence there are lessons that play games, which is a nice break from the 3 hr long lectures. TAs are supportive and knowledgeable as well.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading was not transparent. We got below average in the interim reports while the comment on it was overwhelmingly positive (the only bad thing mentioned was our formatting, which I believe was not a strong enough reason to have such grade). Presentation takes up a huge part of the total grade so be aware.
reviews.comment_workload: Attendance and group work is required for every lesson. There is a quiz for every lesson after mid-term, which is based on 50+ pages of required readings. The time given to prepare each of the two interim reports for the project was tight as well. After all of that there is a reflection essay you need to hand in. Very heavy workload for a 3 credit 1000 level course.

reviews.author: lovecoco
reviews.comment_content: The content is quite interesting if you are interesting in understanding human pollution in different way and solutions.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Discussion in every lessons, and you have to evaluate and being evaluated by your group mates, so participation is important.

Different activities will be held in every lessons to deepen the idea. Usually half of lesson time is lecture and the other half is discussion and activities.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is fair. Some mid-term tests (around 10 mins each), no final exam and the mark of project would not heavily depend on the final product, but disturbed evenly on different stages.

The project can be in different topics depending on which one your group like, such as water pollution and land pollution, and you have to suggest how to solve it. The project requires some information research for statistic and lots of creativity to think of the your original solutions.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is not very heavy, but the schedule is tight. Have work or part of the group project to hand in every week near the end of semester. And group project requires a lot of discussion with group mates and time to complete.

reviews.author: maps
reviews.comment_content:
1. Introduction
2. Anthropogenic (human) impact on natural systems
3. Planetary boundaries and Earth systems
4. Human thriving within planetary boundaries
5. Policy approaches for sustainability
6. Sustainable development and sustainable communities
7. Impact of Covid on SDG
8. Energy futures
9. Futures for fresh water
10. Design for a circular economy
11. Sustainable consumption
12. Futures thinking
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof Delina is a super nice guy, he always tries his best to explain all the concept in class through real life examples, which makes the concepts easier to grasp. Though the class duration is quite long, he always gives 10-15 mins break in between, making it a lot more bearable.
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm (30%) - the format of the midterm was long answer questions. I'd say the grading's relatively lenient.
Mini quizzes (15%) - there are 5 quizzes in total, and they'll choose the best 3 of the 5 that you've completed. The quizzes are done in the beginning of the class. They're relatively short, and will usually test your understanding of the concepts covered in the required readings.
Group project (35%) - in groups of 5, you'll need to create two interim reports that will eventually lead up to a final product of a poster. Each group will be assigned a country and they'll need to each do research about that country's sustainability issues.
Written essay (10%) - in the end of the course, you'll have to write a 800 word essay on a sustainability topic of your choice. They'll usually give you a guiding question to start with.
Class attendance and participation (10%) - there are a lot of class activity in this course, hence, I'd say that attendance is mandatory. Prof Delina tends to always encourage in class participation, hence, I would say that participation marks are not too tough to attain.

Overall, I think the grading's fair. The mean was relatively high, especially for group project related tasks. Hence, it's crucial to find good teammates for the group project.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload's not too heavy. They'll give you weekly readings that will take max 60-90 mins to read, it'll come in handy for the mini quizzes that will be conducted in Part B of the course.

The group project does take some time, but if you have fun teammates to work with, it should not be too burdensome. Plus, because it's a level 1000 course, the tasks itself are not too difficult.

reviews.author: Umang
reviews.title: Overall Easy and good grading
reviews.comment_content: The content is well organised and easy to understand. However, revision is required in the later part of the course for quizzes as you will have weekly quizzes in the second half and the quizzes mostly vary in difficulty level across weeks so be sure to prepare well as some concepts can be abstract. Make sure to interact in the course for good participation scores which are quite important.
reviews.comment_teaching: The teacher is well versed in his material and the TAs were helpful as well
reviews.comment_grading: Very nice grading. Got an A after much effort though.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is on the heavier side if you want to score well. Make sure to create a good poster and focus on the quizzes for maximum chances of a high grade.

reviews.author: Kam Kee :)
reviews.title: Find good group mates before reg
reviews.comment_content:
Part 1:
L1: Introduction
L2: Anthropogenic impact on natural system
L3: Planetary boundary
L4: Human thriving
L5: Policy
L6: Sustainable development
---------------------------------------------
Part 2:
L7: Energy future
L8: Future for water
L9: Circular economy
L10: Sustainable consumption
L11: Future thinking
L12: Zoom presentation

There will be a midterm for Part A content, then mini quiz for Part B before each lesson, so never miss the first 10 minutes of the class
reviews.comment_teaching: Three hour lesson is quite demanding. For the first half of the lesson, it would be purely professor explaining the content for that lesson. Professor can be a bit boring but he tries his best to answer students' questions. The second half would be group activities. Depending on your group mates, if they are willing to speak up, it's actually quite enjoyable.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is quite lenient! Our group had an issue for the final project poster and had to hand it in late. I emailed professor and he said he saw our group resubmitted it, so he wouldn't count us as late. Didn't participate much and I think our group did not have the best project presentation, but I got a B+.

Midterm exam (35%)
Mini quizzes: best 3 out of 5 (15%)
Group project (25%)
Written Essay (15%)
Class attendance and participation (10%)
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload for this course is quite heavy.

For Part B, there is a mini quiz at the start of each lesson, so you will be required to read and understand all the required reading materials beforehand.
The workload for the project is heavy. Two interim reports, with final group poster project and presentation. Had to do a lot of researches and checking for information. Disaster when you have bad group mates, have to do everything yourself.
The midterm exam is open book, but I have to revisit the lecture notes as there is a lot of content. The written essay is a 800-word reflection essay on how to view sustainability.

reviews.author: ayeung
reviews.comment_content: i guess you'll just find out the syllabus from other reviews haha ;D
reviews.comment_teaching: Arthur is a really nice professor, somewhat like a dad figure :D he tries his best to engage with everyone in the class, even if it was only online. you really don't have to worry about embarrassing yourself during lectures cus he is tooooo encouraging haha. he'll definitely rmb everyone (except if you never respond / come to class) since he says hi to every one of us before class starts!
reviews.comment_grading:
i got an A for overall, which is pretty surprising!

1. Interim Report #1 (5%)
- Mean: 4.8/5
- Our group: 4.5/5

2. Interim Report #2 (10%)
- Mean: 9.9/10
- Our group: 9.8/10

3. Poster Presentation (15%)
- Mean: 13.2/15
- Our group: 14.15/15

4. Peer Evaluation for Project (5%)

5. Quizzes (15%)
- best 3/5 of your scores will be counted

6. Mid-Term Exam (30%)
- Mean: 22.7/30
- Me: 27/30

7. Reflection Paper (10%)
- Mean: 8.3/10
- Me: 8.5/10

8. Class Attendance & Participation (10%)
- i participate almost every lecture? but the score isn't released.
reviews.comment_workload:
the most crucial thing about this course is finding good teammates :( there are certain requirements about forming groups like diff schools/years/majors etc.
to me, it's a pretty high workload course since there is class work for every lecture (to be done within the class with your teammates), then a mid-term exam, quizzes about reading materials for every lecture after the mid-term (probably 5 quizzes in the end?), a reflection paper of ard 800 words, not to mention the project zzz
the project includes 2 interim reports and a poster + final presentation, it might seem manageable, but you'll actually have to plan out and sort things out with your teammates!

reviews.author: yoyo.y
reviews.comment_content:
Lecture 2 - Anthropogenic impact on natural systems
Lecture 3 - Planetary boundaries
Lecture 4 - Human Thriving
Lecture 5 - Policy
Lecture 6 - Sustainable Development
Lecture 7 - Energy futures
Lecture 8 - Futures for Water
Lecture 9 - Design for a Circular Economy
Lecture 10 - Sustainable Consumption
Lecture 11 - Futures Thinking

You need to read the slide before the classes (especially after mid-term, the mini-quizzes are related to the slides)
The content is not difficult to understand but a bit long
reviews.comment_teaching:
Half of the lesson is for the important concepts.
Then, half of the lesson is for activities or discussions (with groupmates). The activities (games) are quite interesting.
reviews.comment_grading:
Mid-term Exam(30%)
Mini quizzes * 5 (scores for the highest 3 quizzes) (15%)
Group project (35%) [Two Interim Report (15%) + Poster (15%) + Peer Review (5%)]
Written Essay(10%)
Class attendance and participation (10%)
reviews.comment_workload:
Before mid-term, almost very low workload - just one Interim Report.
After mid-term, the workload is much high. You need to read the slide about p.60-80 before the classes for preparing the mini-quizzes (MC)
And you need to finish another Interim Report, Poster and prepare the presentation.
Finally, you are required to write about 800 words essay.

reviews.author: AWY
reviews.comment_content:
Basic concepts covering what sustainability is from the socio-economic perspectives.

Part A (Mid-term)
1: Introduction
2: Anthropogenic (human) impact on natural systems
3: Planetary boundaries and Earth systems
4: Human thriving within planetary boundaries
5: Policy approaches for sustainability

Part B (mini-quizzes)

reviews.comment_teaching: Interactive class but no as introvert-friendly. Arthur tried to engage everyone in the class and gave each group comments after the presentation.
reviews.comment_grading:
(30%) Midterm exam for part A
(15%) Mini quizzes for Part B
(35%)Group project  [made up of two Interim Reports (15%) + Poster Presentation (15%) + Peer Review (5%)]
(10%) End-of-course Written Essay
(10%) Participation

Marks for interim reports were pretty much similar for every group so mid-term might mean a lot for the grading.

Not sure about the grading yet.
reviews.comment_workload: Manageable workload. Open-book midterm and quizzes so I just went over the materials once and searched during the tests. It's actually quite chill if you could have good teammates for the project. But this course could be torturing for introverts as there were group discussions and presentations every lecture.

reviews.author: hjhjhj

reviews.comment_content:
content is not bad; understandable for non-sci students

reviews.author: supermin
reviews.title: Lots of things to do. But good course overall.
reviews.comment_content:
Contents are not too difficult. Doing some memorization helps a lot

L1 - Introduction
L2 - Anthropogenic Impact on Natural Systems
L3 - Planetary Boundaries
L4 - Human Thriving
L5 - Policy
L6 - Sustainable Development
L7 - Energy
L8 - Fresh Water
L9 - Designing a Circular Economy
L10 - Sustainable Consumption
L11 - Futures

Syllabus is attached.
reviews.comment_teaching:
She is very kind and will answer any question raised in class or off class.

Her English is very good and fluent, so no problems in understanding her lectures.

She gives out slides prior to her lectures, and you should read it through at least once to do the quizzes, and to understand the flow of the lecture. Slides are in good format and well organized.

TAs are great as well. They will also answer any questions raised.
reviews.comment_grading:
Participation and Attendance 10%
     Join classes and answer questions actively to get high marks.
Midterm Exam 35%
     Five Long answer questions.
     Not too difficult if you understand the lectures.
Mini Quizzes 15%
     Five MC questions at beginning of lecture, from after midterms.
     Best three out of five are counted.
Group Project 25%
     Prepare TWO progress reports + ONE poster and presentation.
     Make sure to get good teammates.
     Also not too difficult if work is properly assigned.
Written Assignment 15%
     Writing up short essays on given topics
  
I had good teammates so group projects were 2nd in class
Midterms and Quizzes were slightly above mean
Written Assignment was 1sd above

Final grade was B+
slightly disappointing but is acceptable.
reviews.comment_workload:
There's quite a lot you need to do.

Reading prior to class (recommended if you want good quiz grades)
Quizzes
Midterms
2 Group Essay
1 Group Project + Presentation
1 Essay after presentation (more like reflection-like)

Compulsory to join classes because there are lots of discussions and they are graded to participation!

Not recommended if you don't like talking too much or introvert.
Recommended if you are interested in Sustainability and Environment, and if you don't mind talking in class.

reviews.author: csheep

reviews.comment_teaching:
Benjamin' teaching is interesting. His lectures won't let you feel boring. Half of the lectures are used for group exercises (easy for group exercises!!) But be prepared to present your idea in front of the class.

MOST IMPORTANTLY, his PPT is very detailed. Just read all required reading (normally over 50 slides of PPT) then it is sufficient for midterm/ quiz.
reviews.comment_grading:
35% midterm
15% short quizzes (do 5 count best 3)
10% 2 interim paper
10% group poster
5% Peer Evaluation
15% reflection paper
10% participation

Midterm is super easy. (open book exam)
If you can get full mark in the midterm, then can secure A range.
But it also depends on your group mates, if your group mates did not provide high quality work to the report or presentation, then you will be in troubles.

Overall, this course is a "good-grading" course.
reviews.comment_workload:
Actually light workload, but be careful to the deadlines of report.
The professor/ TA may not remind you one/two weeks before the submission of report.

If you have taken DSE GEOG/LS, then this course will be super easy for you.

reviews.author: Fab
reviews.comment_content:
Decent content imo, but take into consideration that this is my first course on sustainability in my entire life lol. Interesting content and easy to grasp if you pay attention which is the hardest since the lecture is like 3hrs...

However, there's quite a number of slides containing graphs, statistics, and quantitative data that wasn't tested on and is just there for your information so ask the professor about the content.

Mid term - only the first few topics are tested
Short 5 minute MC Quiz for the rest of the topics at the beginning of class. (only your best 3 are counted)

There's also two lectures with games which I found enjoyable (fishing game and loop boardgame)

Anthropogenic (human) impact on natural systems
Planetary boundaries and Earth systems
Human thriving within planetary boundaries
Policy approaches for sustainability
Sustainable development and sustainable
communities
Energy futures
Futures for fresh water
Design for a circular economy
Sustainable consumption
reviews.comment_teaching: Great professor, super kind, enthusiastic, great energy, interactive with the class.
reviews.comment_grading:
Not too sure how grading works, I got a B+ from:
Mid term: 31/35 well above mean
Quiz: 4.5/5, 4.5/5, 5/5 (best 3 out of 5 quiz)
Group project: always below mean >:( probably dragged my grade down
reviews.comment_workload:
Readings every week (presentation slides 30-70slides cant rmber, its around there), no biggie, spend some time reading before class.

Group project: depends on your group members, we didn't put a whole lot effort but always split the work evenly.

That's about it.

Recommend taking this course.

reviews.author: huich
reviews.title: Content is quite boring but a good grade course
reviews.comment_content: An introductory course about sustainability. The course is separated into two parts: challenges of sustainability (first half of course) and futures for human thriving within planetary boundaries (second half of course). The content is quite boring as it is just about the basics of sustainability and what humans can do to help the environment.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor can be a bit boring but he tries his best to answer students' questions. It is a three-hour lesson so the second half of the lesson is a group activity. The group activities are fun sometimes (e.g. games).
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is quite lenient! Slighty above mean for both group project and midterm exam with full marks for mini quiz. Did not participate much in class. My final grade was A.

Midterm exam (35%)
Mini quizzes (15%)
Group project (25%)
Written Essay (15%)
Class attendance and participation (10%)
reviews.comment_workload: Workload for this course is quite heavy. There are required readings before the class for the second half of the course, as there is a mini quiz at the start of each lesson. The workload for the project is heavy, with group poster+presentation and two group interim reports. The midterm exam is open book, but preparation is needed because there is quite a lot of content. The written essay is a short 800-word reflection essay on sustainability.

reviews.author: LapisDoughnut
reviews.title: Challenge yourself, go for Sust 1000
reviews.comment_content:
CONTENT

Part 1:
L1: Introduction
L2: Anthropogenic impact on natural system
L3: Planetary boundary
L4: Human thriving
L5: Policy
L6: Sustainable development
---------------------------------------------
Part 2:
L7: Energy future
L8: Future for water
L9: Circular economy
L10: Sustainable consumption
L11: Future thinking

L12: Video presentation

Part A is for the mid-term, and there will be a short quiz in front of every lectures of Part B so that it is essential to make preparations before every lectures.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof is quite an interactive person and shares most of his experiences during lesson time.
I would say it can be entertaining enough because there are interactive activities and games, but definitely a hell for introverts like me.
reviews.comment_grading:
This is the part I would say "What the-" in the course.
Here's the mix of the whole course:
35% midterm
15% short quizzes (do 5 count best 3)
10% 2 interim paper
10% group poster
5% Peer Evaluation
15% reflection paper
10% participation

The midterm and quizzes are fair grading given that there are clear answers, but the problem is about the report part (Interim paper+ Group poster).

Wang Rui, the TA responsible for our group is a really interesting person.
We followed the guidelines of the 1st interim report so we tried to include every part listed on the guidelines as possible given there is a limitation on word count, he says "too broad". Low Mark.
Therefore we focused in the main points of the guidelines for the 2nd report, and this time he says "a lack of comprehensiveness". Low mark.

I tried to ask how should we improve our report in lessons between the deadline of two submissions, even he is looking at the screen he continues to mute as if nothing happened.
Not a great grade for me coz the report part is really disappointing, even I am above the mean for the midterm and quizzes.

I regard this as a lottery instead. If you have other TAs marking your paper, you could strike for better grades. If you got Wang Rui, prepare for the harshest marking scheme while at the same time not receiving any comments of improvements from him.

This is a course of absolute grading, any minor mistakes hurts a lot.
reviews.comment_workload:
I would say the workload is quite appropriate. Not too heavy and not too light.
1 Mid-term covering the whole Part A,
5 quizzes for every lecture of Part B,
a group work consisted of 2 interim paper and 1 poster, and finally 1 reflection paper.

reviews.author: mkk
reviews.comment_content: A bit lengthy but easy in terms of understanding. 3 hours lecture is a hassle but except that it seems alright to cope with. Reading before class help in class discussions and are important for the exams.
reviews.comment_teaching: Interactive teaching with multiple games used to explain concepts. TAs were helpful and help explain the concepts alongside the professor.
reviews.comment_grading: Very fair and good grading. Scored just above mean in the exam, Mean in the presentation and just above mean in the reflection.
reviews.comment_workload: Decent workload. If you pay attention in class its not that tough.

reviews.author: Nicole Lee
reviews.comment_content:
This is a great choice as both a SSC- ST or SSC-SA course, especially if you're not looking for heavily science related courses. The content are mostly surrounding environmental issues and topics that have mostly been taught in high school (in biology or geography).

Syllabus
L1: Introduction
L2: Anthropogenic Impacts on Natural System
L3: Planetary Boundaries for Human Thriving
L4: Humans Thriving
L5: Policy and Public Action For a Sustainable Future
L6: Sustainable Development
Midterm
L7: Energy
L8: Future For Water
L9: Circular Economy
L10: Sustainable Consumption
L11: Future Thinking
L12: Video presentation
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor is very nice and welcoming. He is open to questions whenever you ask both in class or through emails. He is also very open to suggestions to help improve his classes. We did games and did interesting activities which made the classes generally more entertaining since it is almost a 3 hour class!! He also gives us breaks (even on zoom) to help improve our concentration.
reviews.comment_grading: The grade is determined by weekly followup worksheets, midterm, group project and reflection essay. The worksheets are not hard to complete if you divide the work up evenly among your group and answer the questions accurately. The midterm is a little difficult since the time is quite limited. Memorize all content including specific examples for the midterm. The group project is not difficult but is research heavy. There is also a Q&A session where you are asked questions by a panel of experts (professor and some other guests), this is the most challenging part of the whole course as they are very strict and critical when questioning about your solutions (group project).
reviews.comment_workload: The overall workload depends on your group mates (find good ones!!) since the group project and worksheets are all done as a group. You also need to discuss very often during classes and do tasks together. For final project, divide the tasks evenly and get everyone to answer questions during the Q&A panel.

reviews.author: Tyhxd
reviews.comment_content: The content is quite straightforward and easy to understand. PowerPoint slides in the lessons is mainly the stuff you have to read for the exams and projects.
reviews.comment_teaching: Arthur's teaching is fair and there are lots of activities organised during the lessons, which can be annoying or interesting based on your perspective.
reviews.comment_grading: His grading for project is a little bit bad in my opinion. But the grading for exams is ok and fair.
reviews.comment_workload: The lessons are so long and can be very tiring, which can be good or bad based on your perspective as there is only one lengthy lesson per week. Attendance is also required.

reviews.comment_content:
Stuff related to environmental issues with many specific terms.  
Don't join this course if your English is really bad.
Suitable for hk students who are good at LS because you need to write a lot of meaningless words and construct a framework to explain your ideas.
reviews.comment_teaching: The prof. was quite nice with his Konglish accent. There were lots of presentations in class, nearly one per each lesson.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is ok. Make sure your groupmates are good and responsible since the final project took us 40% of the grading. I shit the project which is below mean a little bit but I got all above mean in my written tasks then I just got into B range.
Also, attend every single lesson because you have 99% of chance to have a small group presentation in front of the class and that will be counted as your participation.
PS: I think it is better to make the prof. remembers you (otherwise I probably get a lower grade because of my project ;))
reviews.comment_workload:
I think the workload is acceptable, we got one midterm, one final project and one reflection to be finished. There is no final. Although the prof. told us to read the ppt before coming to class, I never done that and that's still ok because the prof. will go through the slides with us finally. I only got tired by this course when having the lesson because I don't want to speak up in the class at all but you need to ;)
Last but not least, the workload of this course actually depends on your group ;))))))

reviews.author: hii123
reviews.comment_content:
The course would also cover quite a lot of contents, and the concepts are mostly about geology and sustainability, yet the content is relatively easier when compared to other Common Core courses.

The course would be divided into two parts. Part A would be explaining some key terms from the geography or anthropology field. Quite a lot of technical terms need to be memorized if you haven't studied Geography before. Part B would be covering the specific topics that are related to sustainability, such as energy consumption, fresh water usage etc. These topics are interesting as they are mostly related to daily issues.

The course mainly consists of 2 grading parts, the project, and the midterm paper. For details, please refer to the latter part.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Students are required to read a PowerPoint before going to class. The PowerPoint would be mainly about technical knowledge, which will be assessed in the midterm exam.

The classes are interactive. The lecturer would throw out some questions and discussion would be carried out in a group format. Then the group would have to present their consensus in front of the whole class.

BTW, there is only 1 lecture per week, and each lecture would last for around 3 hours. Therefore, sometimes you may find the lecture boring.
reviews.comment_grading:
Mid-term Exam (35%)
Part 1 will require short answers to well-focused questions.    
Part 2 will require longer, more open-ended responses to issues.

Group project (40%)
- Pick 3 SDGs and investigate the SDG development in a chosen country.
- Complete a poster design and there will be an in-class presentation

Reflection paper (15%)
- Reflect what you learn from the course

Class participation (10%)
- Be active in class

Generally, the sd for the group presentation, reflection paper, and class participation is very small. The only area that you could outperform in the class would be doing well in the midterm paper since the SD is quite high. If you are able to score 1-1.5 sd above the midterm paper and get a mean score for the rest, I think you are safe to get at least a B or B+.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is not very heavy. I usually don't read the PowerPoint before class. It's OKIE to study them one to two weeks before the midterm.

Each group would also have to complete a total of 5 research reports. They usually give out the research guidance 45 mins before the class ended and your group could complete it either within that 45 mins or after class. If the work is being evenly distributed, the workload is actually not that high.

There is also a group project, which is to design a poster to illustrate the SDG development in a given country.

reviews.author: kero星人
reviews.comment_content:
So DSE LS like, in blended learning mode. Some are overlap with LIFS1030.
Personally think contents are quite easy, except factual stuff are much to memorise for midterm
First half will be more factual, required more understanding through self learn and will be examed in midterm
Second half is just project based, about sustainability goals of a specific country appointed, which four worksheets are done in class and only three count. Not difficult but need online researches. Some require submission in class, some 1 hour after class, and some 24 hours after class.
A poster have to be completed based on the content in ws, and a presentation for three groups of assessor (10 min), but beware the time management and mode of assess for each grp are different.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Very interactive, class activity and discussion every class.
My class Prof Lu is a very nice professor, and teach passionately. However, he has mandarin accent and not quite a funny one. I like his delivery style anyway :)
After midterm, the other two prof would take turns and deliver class to all sessions for the same lecture.
Prof Lau is a old style HK prof, do activities that are meaningless, eg measure water flow from tap which is kind of wastage of water.
reviews.comment_grading:
Quite good.
Attendance, ws, and participation are easy to full marks.
reviews.comment_workload:
Fair workload for project and reflection essay. Need to remember all ppt contents for midterm

Midterm: write more than you need. Eg for choosing the important sustainable development goals in HK, 1 pt is given for suggestion of ways to improve HK
short questions + an essay question

Project: having good groupmates are important (which must be compost of diff year and major)

Essay: 500 words reflection for what you learnt and how it changed your vision.

reviews.author: Tunaaaa
reviews.comment_content: The content covered in class was very broad, and it teaches little stuff in every area. Its mostly memorising since it's hard to relate most of the content to our lives.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor is very nice and talkative. She likes to interact with students and ask about how we think. There are also break time for us to relax after taking in the massive information in class.
reviews.comment_grading: Some of the grades are easy to get, like the participation mark and class work. The professor gives us time to work in group for the class work which makes it easier to work on. However for the final grade, which is based on a poster, is very bad.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is mainly from reading the powerpoint provided  since there're a lot of slides in every powerpoint. The class work wasn't that hard, since there is a lot of time to work on it.

reviews.author: don11669
reviews.title: Maybe a choice for Year 1 students with the new, LS-like mid-term
reviews.comment_content: The course title is quite self-explanatory. It is basically an introduction on what is sustainability, what affect sustainability, and possible approaches to handle challenges to sustainability. For my own opinion, it is quite interesting that the course kept telling us how our daily behavior, other than policies, affect sustainability, and allow us to think what can we do daily as well as which approaches do we support and prefer for making our society more sustainable.  Maybe a little difficult to understand some of the content though.
reviews.comment_teaching: One 3-hour lesson per week. This term the entire Part A is taught by one instructor, and instructors of other sessions came to teach in each other's lesson for Part B. Reading material is an important part of the course, we were expected to have done the reading, so on lesson they would rather introduce examples or having activities related to the concepts mentioned in the reading materials, mostly without repeating them. However the fact is most students didn't have a look of the reading materials at all, but due to the fact that they focus more on discussions and activities in class, you still won't have a really bad time in lesson, and can always look at the reading material in lesson if necessary. Overall, lessons were quite inspiring and led us to think.
reviews.comment_grading:
Mid-term Exam (35%)
It seems like it is the first time we got a mid-term for this course. It involves content in Part A, and question type is quite similar to DSE LS, except you have to remember and use specific concepts from the reading materials, such as Planetary Boundaries, SDGs etc. , which would be stated in the questions.
Mean: 24.4 High: 32.6 Low: 0

Take-home, written assignment (15%)
One written assignment on a given topic at the end of the course. They said they expect around 800 words, but I made it almost 1000 words and some maybe even longer. They mentioned that something like a diary entry rather than an essay is expected.
Mean: 11.8 High: 14 Low: 0

Class attendance and participation (10%)
They takes attendance in each class and expect participation in in-class discussion. There were some really active students and they often raise questions of others conclusion on activities, thus discussions can happen anytime in class!
Mean: 6.9 High: 10

Group project (40%)
-15% for project worksheets done in week 7-10, each per week, and only the best 3 worksheets will be counted
-20% for poster and presentation done in week 13, which is about sustainability challenges and possible solutions in a specific, assigned country, and project worksheets can help its accomplishment a lot
-5% for peer reviews
Mean: 20 High: 23.6 Low: 14.5

30.1/35 for mid-term, 13/15 for reflection paper, 9.5/10 for participation, 14.4/15 for project worksheets, 21.7/25 for poster&presentation+peer review--->A

I would say you can get a satisfying grade as long as you do treat this course seriously, and as the mid-term has a similar mode as DSE LS, maybe Year 1 student would get a little bit advantage.
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload is quite light. Students were expected to read the reading material given every week before the lesson, which is around 70-80 pages of slides for Part A, and 50-60 pages for Part B. Mid-term Exam was basically set on the slides in Part A, and the content of them were mostly not repeated at lessons, so make sure you do read them. However, for Part B, those materials may not help a lot on the group project, but it will always be better to read them so that you understand easier what's going on at the lessons.

Among the 4 project worksheets, 2 of them with deadlines set at 24 hours after the lesson may require a little bit research on the Internet after lesson, but it didn't really take much time for me.

With all the project worksheets, the project also wouldn't bring too much workload, as long as you don't meet a full group of free- riders. Luckily, all of us in my group were willing to work, so workload is not too high for each of us.

reviews.author: lonelyguy
reviews.comment_content:
The content was actually difficult and vague as you cannot relate the concept to daily life context. It makes me difficult to fully understanding those environmental concepts given that I am a business student. Yet, the contents were interesting after the midterm exam.

Week 1: Introduction
Week 2: Anthropogenic (human) impact on natural systems
Week 3: Planetary boundaries and Earth systems
Week 4: Holiday
Week 5: Human thriving within planetary boundaries and strategies for sustainability
Week 6: Policy approaches for sustainability
Week 7: Sustainable development and sustainable communities
Week 8: Energy futures
Week 9: Futures for freshwater
Week 10: Urban futures
Week 11: Sustainable consumption and design for a circular economy
Week 12: Future
Week 13: Final project presentations
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Meike is super nice. She always smiled at us and provided a casual and interactive learning atmosphere. She loved asking questions and answering her questions could gain class participation mark as well.

Her class was 9 am class, so it was actually quite hard for students to attend a 3 hour class per week. But, many students would attend her lessons, perhaps attendance counting was one of the reasons.

After midterm, her colleagues would teach some topics and I did not really love it as the consistency might be affected and their other professors were actually quite creepy. Luckily I did not choose their lectures.
reviews.comment_grading:
Fair grading. This semester they added Mid Term Exam which it did not appear in the past few years. So, we did not have any sources and the format was unclear as well. The weighting was too heavy and it becomes the grade differentiator since everyone gets a similar score in other components, even in the project.

35% Mid-term Exam (23.8/35 Mean: 25.7)
15% Reflection Paper (11.5/15 Mean: 10.8)
10% Attendance and Participation (8/10 Mean: 7.4)
40% Group project (36.04/40 Mean: 33.5)
- 15% Project Worksheet (best 3 out of 4)
- 5% Peer Evaluation
- 20% Poster and Presentation

Final Grade: B (79.3%)
80% B+, 4% every sub-grade
reviews.comment_workload:
A 3-hour class. Only 1 lecture per week so the workload was fine.

Have powerpoint slide before class and they expected you to read them but every chapter's slides were 80 pages long and you won't understand all of those concepts. Yet, they won't repeat too much on those concepts bruh.

The project was fine but required students from different school and year which was a bit nonsense in some ways, yet it means that you may not be able to stick with your friends to do the project together.

Starting from week 8, your group will have to finish a project worksheet in class. First 2 worksheets only allow you to finish within 1 hour. The last 2 worksheets have 1 day for you to finish it. Yet, the grade for every group is high.

reviews.author: 淺水健
reviews.comment_content: for the content of the course, it is similar to the LS course in our secondary school. Concerning social issues. But the topic of the assignment is not clear, they give a sentence of topic and you need to write two 800 words essay and hand in in mid-term and final period .
reviews.comment_teaching: teaching is boring, they just buy some snack to attract student to participate the class, many of us leave the lesson during break time.
reviews.comment_grading: grading not so good
reviews.comment_workload: there are not so many workload in this course, just one ppt before each lesson. It is optional to read and the instructor will ask questions that content about those information during lesson. If you want to get all 5 marks of class performance, that will be a good choice for you to do it

reviews.author: smallpotato tom
reviews.title: Not bad not good
reviews.comment_content:
diversified, but not easy to follow all materials

at least this course made me think a lot

but a lot of materials are quite hard, just like those in MECH1906
reviews.comment_teaching: some kind of bore, but he always gives snack break in the middle of lesson
reviews.comment_grading:
i got 2 quiz full marks, 3 quiz around mean

all individual reports got above mean

grade around 'mean' in the final project

B-
reviews.comment_workload:
no homework
