pop quiz in every lesson

if you got good project partners, it is better

reviews.author: cynnie
reviews.title: Fair grading, okay workload
reviews.comment_content: Well in general, the content is about the sustainability of environment in different aspects, like overfishing or biosphere. Sometimes the content is really easy for instance global warming, but sometimes it requires some knowledge in biology to understand the life cycle
reviews.comment_teaching: A generally really interactive course as the professor tries to engage all the students to join in class discussions or activities. The slides used in classes are also different from the slides required to prepare beforehand, so it won’t be that repetitive.
reviews.comment_grading: Fair grading. I got slightly above mean for all assignments, quizzes and presentation, ended up with a B+.
reviews.comment_workload: I would say the workload is adequate considering that there are no midterms or no finals:)

reviews.author: ggyyfku
reviews.title: normal grading course
reviews.comment_content: It would be difficult to catch up if you did not take any chemistry and geography as electives in secondary school
reviews.comment_teaching:
every time they taught with ppt,
questions and worksheets are designed for students to discuss in group on the lessons.
the only thing i like is that they provide free snack( biscuits and grapes) during break :D
reviews.comment_grading:
normal grading
not so-called "good grade course"
reviews.comment_workload:
almost has quiz in  every lesson.
Quiz contains 5 mc/sq
No midterm and final
but have two assignments and one project
Quizzes contains 25%, participation  in class contains 5%,
2 assignments contains  30% and
Group project  40% on total grade.

reviews.author: ustkidhere
reviews.title: Grading system could be improved
reviews.comment_content: The content is fairly easy and provides a good insight into the issues of sustainability.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Teaching style includes interactive powerpoints and group discussions, which are very different from the usual lectures. It's a fun way to learn if you hate spoonfeeding lecture styles.

Best part is, since this is a 3 hour lecture, halfway through you get a 10 minute break and they provide snacks. It's absolutely sweet of the professors to do this and encourages students to attend the lectures.
reviews.comment_grading:
Doesn't take attendance but there are quizzes during the beginning of some lectures about the required reading.

In-class comprehension quizzes  25%
Class participation  5%
Take-home assignments  30%
Group project  40%

The in-class quizzes are written in a way that the answer is questionable and can be debated. There have also been several mistakes in the in-class quizzes so hopefully they'll have corrected and improved these for the next semester.

Take-home assignments include writing two short essays that don't require much research, but rather your thoughts on the course and topic of sustainability in general.

Beware of the heavy grading for the group project. If you get free-riders then you're going to have more workload so the advice is, get the other marks from participation, in-class quizzes and take-home assignments so you worry less about the group project.
reviews.comment_workload: Compared to other courses, the workload is higher but if you like what you're learning, it shouldn't be too tough. You can finish the take-home assignments in less than a day. The one that requires most work is the group project, where you'll have to meet up with your groupmates for research and prep for presentation.

reviews.author: kentanggoreng
reviews.title: New interesting yet really messy course
reviews.comment_content: It has a really broad content regarding sustainability, from its science perpective, toward business and engineering perspective. The class was heavy on lectures but shifted toward interaction in a small classroom.
reviews.comment_teaching: Some instructors were enjoyable, some were total crap. Karen is not teaching anymore next semester so I guess there will be more crap instructors than decent ones. Oops. :)
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading was OK, but I think for very easy quizzes and project assignment, they shouldn't had curved the course. I was scared for my life waiting for my grades.

The group project was worth 60% percent, which was hella lot, compared to the amount of workload we had to do.
reviews.comment_workload:
5 quizzes, only 4 taken into final grade. 10% each. They started giving really short and easy quizzes (5 to 10 multicle choices) but changed it to a more problem solving essay kind of questions in the middle of the course. They were still "treading the water" and used us as guinea pigs. I think giving 5-MC-quiz a 10% weight is a bit saddistic, but some people like it that way.
There's no midterm and no finals. Only a group project that worth 60 whopping percent. Group members were randomized. You had to pick one out of 6 instructors as your mentor.

reviews.author: janette
reviews.title: fair grading, low workload, but be aware of the heavy weighting of group project
reviews.comment_content: mostly simple concepts based on high school knowledge
reviews.comment_teaching:
5-6 lecturer in total.
each of them comes from departments of engineering, science and  business schools respectively
Every lecturer has their own teaching style.
some read powerpoints only, some encourage student discussion.
reviews.comment_grading: quite good, mean is around B to B+
reviews.comment_workload:
the workload is quite low.

1.Short in-class quizzes at the end of key sections of the course (40%)
2. Completion of a project to be presented in the final sessions of the course (60%)
In-class quizzes

There will be 5 in-class quizzes, each worth 10% of the total course grade. Your best four results will be counted to the final grade

reviews.author: G1gi
reviews.title: Good common core course!
reviews.comment_content:
Assessment

Mid-term Exam (30%)
Open book exam, common to all sections, covering Part A (Lecture 1-6) of the course (2-hour exam).

Mini quizzes (15%)
Starting from Part B, a short quiz is conducted for each lecture to test our basic understanding of the concepts covered in the required readings, different to all sections. Each quiz will account for 5 points. The best three out of five quizzes will count towards the final grade.

Group project (35%)
We worked in groups to research and identify the key sustainability challenges and provide possible solutions for a selected world region.

Two Interim Reports (15%)
Two interim reports are required to report on the progress of the project.

Interim report #1 (5%) – a broad overview of the selected countries' situation
Interim report #2 (10%) – evaluation of sustainability challenges in the selected country

Poster (15%)
A poster concisely detailing the findings is presented during the final lecture. There were individual Q&A sessions with the instructors. We also received questions and feedback from your peers.

Peer Review (5%)
5pt of the grade was from peer evaluations based on the student's contribution to the group project. Comments were mandatory and reviewed by the instructional team to ensure fairness in evaluation.


Written Essay (10%)
There was one short (800-word) written assignment to demonstrate our overall understanding of the issues covered in the course.

Class attendance and participation (10%)

The course included in-class activities and discussions to facilitate student learning. 7% of the grade is given for attendance and in-class participation (proactive in discussions and activities, interactions with instructors, TAs and peers, etc). 3% of the grade was on the peer evaluation of our group members based on their contributions during in-class activities.
reviews.comment_teaching: Meike is a good instructor, very friendly with excellent English. She managed to deliver the lectures and activities clearly, and we always had a chance to share our ideas. The class activities are fun and interesting.
reviews.comment_grading:
GOOD GRADE!

For our class:
LQ: 70.85/100
MEAN: 76.67/100
UQ: 87.18/100
ME: 84.85/100
My final grade: A-

Even though you don't hit the upper quartile, you still have the chance to get A range
reviews.comment_workload:
I won't say the workload is heavy when you have good time management.

Part A content of the course will be tested in midterm only. There is not much to memorize as it is concept based, and we had an open-book exam (A4 papers were allowed).

Part B content about SDGs will be tested in the quiz, and knowledge will be helpful for the project. There is also nothing to memorize as all the quizzes are open-book. Note that it is hard to score full points as there will be a mark deduction when you choose a wrong answer.

Some people may be stressed out about scoring more in-class participation. I am also introverted and shy, but I still managed to score full marks for class participation by typing answers/ comments on Zoom and presenting our group's ideas occasionally.

reviews.author: GorGor123321
reviews.title: SUST1000 short review
reviews.comment_content:
Easy concepts related to sustainability

L1 - Introduction
L2 - Anthropogenic Impact on Natural Systems
L3 - Planetary Boundaries
L4 - Human Thriving
L5 - Policy
L6 - Sustainable Development
L7 - Energy
L8 - Fresh Water
L9 - Design for a Circular Economy
L10 - Sustainable Consumption
L11 - Futures Thinking
L12- Poster presentation and sharing
reviews.comment_teaching:
Interactive and relaxing mode of teaching skill is used.
It requires quite a lot group discussions which counted as participation marks. Long lecture (3 hours) but very interactive. First half is the traditional teaching (textbook), second half are the group discussion, some funny games, some videos.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is fair. I have above mean in every assignments included the short quizzes and midterm.
Overall, I have a A-.

All of my scores are above mean,

Mid-term Exam (30%)
24/30

Group project (35%)
Including two group reports and poster presentation

Mini quizzes (15%)
5 mini quizzes but only the best 3 will be counted
Me: 11/15

Reflective Essay (10%)
9.5/10 (Highest)

Class attendance and participation (10%)
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is fair. The group projects are very important. Those short quizzes are quite challenging which may test some minor stuffs in notes. Better spend more time in the revision of short quizzes.

reviews.author: sunshine&tmr
reviews.comment_content: Provides students  with a holistic, interdisciplinary, evidence-based understanding of the challenge  of  ensuring  the  sustainability  of  humanity  on  a  planet  with  limited  natural  and  social capacities. The course introduces frameworks, approaches and key trade-offs underpinning efforts to deal with existing and emerging global issues, and considers how these problems relate to  our  own lifestyles.
reviews.comment_teaching: Engaging, frequently holds discussions in-class. Appreciative to students' contributions, gives positive and constructive feedback. TA Liu and Chen are very responsible and helpful. Instructor is also friendly and willing to answer students' enquiries.
reviews.comment_grading:
Quite Good.

Mid-term Exam (30%) on first half of course content
Mini quizzes (15%) Counts best 3 out of 5. Make sure you are very attentive and awake when doing them.
Group project (35%) - 2 Interim Reports & 1 Poster Presentation
Written Essay (10%) - Reflection Paper
Class attendance and participation (10%) - Peer Review (3%), Attendance (3.5%), In-class engagement (3.5%)
reviews.comment_workload:
Satisfactory.
But significant increase in workload from the second half of the class, since you have to handle mini quizzes weekly, Interim Report 2, Poster & Reflection Paper.

reviews.author: samyuktha
reviews.title: Requires a lot of participation
reviews.comment_content:
1. Introduction
2. Anthropogenic (human) impact on natural systems
3. Planetary boundaries and Earth systems
4. Human thriving within planetary boundaries
5. Policy approaches for sustainability
6. Sustainable development and sustainable communities
7. Energy futures
8. Futures for freshwater
9. Design for a circular economy
10. Sustainable consumption
11. Futures thinking
reviews.comment_teaching:
The Professor is someone who is open to everyone's point of view. Even if it is wrong he will never say it to your face but will twist it a bit so that everyone in class understands what the correct point is. The first half an hour of the course is all about reviewing slides he assigns and possibly a mini quiz. The next half an hour involves group activities and presentations where you really get to participate in class.

DO PARTICIPATE IN CLASS ITS SUPER SUPER IMPORTANT.
reviews.comment_workload: While its a bit hard to sit through a 3 hour class (especially if online) you're done with majority of the workload for this course within the first half of the semester since midterm counts for 50% of grades. Mostly based on qualitative and factual reasoning they look for essay type answers in the assignments and exams.

reviews.author: M.J.
reviews.comment_content: This course is an introductory sustainability course, which is generally easy to understand.
reviews.comment_teaching: Generally, each lecture is divided into three parts. In the first part, Benjamin explains the concepts of sustainability. In the second part, we need to do group exercises in breakout rooms. In the last part, we will go back to the main room and each group needs to present their ideas of the group exercises. Benjamin will give comments after each group presents its ideas. So, this course is relatively interactive, as you do not need to be lectured for the whole of 3 hours.
reviews.comment_grading:
It is an intensely competitive common core course. I do not know the grading scheme of this course. Even though I sent an email to the TA and the professsor, they did not tell me the grading scheme and the cut-off scores of each sub-grade. I guess our performance is graded by curve.

The marking scheme of the group project is ambiguous. Even though our group tried to fulfill all requirements, we still did not get a high mark. We created a group poster with high quality, which might be better than others. But the mark we got in the poster was below mean.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload of this course is neither too heavy nor too light. It is generally acceptable. But you still have a lot of work to do.

reviews.author: summm
reviews.comment_content:
everything about sustainability and UN SDGs

first half of the course (materials for midterm)
1. Introduction
2. Anthropogenic impact on natural systems
3. Planetary boundaries
4. Human thriving
5. Policy
6. Sustainable development
----
second half of the course (materials for mini quiz at the start of each lesson)
7. Energy futures
8. Futures for fresh water
9. Design for a circular economy
10. Sustainable consumption
11. Futures thinking
reviews.comment_teaching:
haven't listen much in class because the lesson time is too long and it is hard to stay awake during class

even though the professor often spells his words incorrectly and has a weird accent, but i can feel that he has his own passion in sustainability and he really does have hope that the world will not blow up (lol)
reviews.comment_grading:
midterm: 35%

mini quizzes (for each lesson of the second half of the course): 15%
- choose 3 out of 5 mini quizzes

group project: 25%
- 2 interim report (5%*2)
- poster (10%)
- peer review (5%)

written essay: 15%
- similar to reflection essay and guidelines will be given

class attendance and participation: 10%

my results:
midterm: 31/35 (mean: 27.9)
mini quizzes: 15/15
group project:
- interim report 1: 4.68/5 (mean: 4.5)
- interim report 2: 3.6/5 (mean: 3.8)
- poster presentation: 10/10 (mean: 7.9)
- peer: 5/5
reflection paper: 12/15
participation: did not release grades; but i have participated in class discussions for 3 or 4 times in class (which is not a lot compared to many people who are actually very active) and presented class activity tasks in class for a few times
-- final grade: A
I originally thought that the grades will be quite competitive and there might be a narrow curve, but in the end I got an A, so I guess grading is quite good.
reviews.comment_workload:
as expected

learning about sustainability stuff means that there are a lot of projects and research, so if you want to reg this, expect doing research, thinking innovative ideas, writing reports, reading pre-lecture notes before class these stuff etc

i think the workload is a bit big for me as the projects deadlines and midterms were always near my other course assignments or midterms so i end up having consecutive days of deadlines or midterms

quite satisfied tho seeing yourself start from scratch in the interim reports and then creating an A1 poster and present your whole idea to prof and TA

reviews.author: freebus
reviews.title: SUST 1000
reviews.comment_content:
Part A (Mid-term Content)
1. Anthropocene and Sustainability
2. Anthropogenic Impact on Natural Systems
3. Planetary Boundaries for Human Thriving
4. Human Thriving Within Planetary Boundaries
5. Policy and Public Action for a Sustainable Future
6. Sustainable Development

Part B (No-one-cares Content)
7. Futures for Energy
8. Futures for Fresh Water
9. Design for a Circular Economy
10. Sustainable Consumption
11. Preferred Futures
reviews.comment_teaching:
The professor is nice and friendly. Every lesson (3 hr) is divided into three sections:
(i) Introduction (going through the required reading slides that you should have studied before class)
(ii) Activities or Games (divided into groups of 4-5, having individual tasks and/or group discussions, and presenting to the class)
(iii) Conclusion (going through remaining slides)
You should always be ready to answer questions, i.e. about the required reading or the in-class discussion, which forces you to pay attention during class. The professor will random pick people to make sure everyone is participating, around ten times per lesson. But you will be fine with the questions because the professor will praise every reply for real.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grade Distribution: A – 25%; B – 50%; C – 23-25%; D/F – 2%

1. Midterm Exam – 35%
2. Group Project – 40%
-- In-class Worksheets (Lesson 6, 7, 8, 9) – 15% (5% each, best 3 out of 4)
-- Presentation (Lesson 12) – 15%
-- Peer-review – 10%
3. Reflection Assignment – 15%
-- 800 words maximum
-- 3 questions answering in one essay
4. In-class Engagement – 10%
-- Attendance – 5%
-- Participation – 5%

Midterm Exam: 33.25/35 (Mean: 25.2/35)
In-class Worksheets: 14.5/15 (Mean: 13.5/15)
Presentation & Peer-review: 23.6/25 (Mean: 21.3/25)
Reflection Assignment: 12/15 (Mean: 11.3/15)
In-class Engagement: 8/10 (Mean: 8/10)

Overall: 91.35/100 (Mean: 79.3/100)
Grade: A+

Midterm has the largest SD, so doing well in midterm means everything. The range of other assessments are always within 1-2 marks.
reviews.comment_workload: Average workload if no free rider in your group, but it won't be very light in general.

reviews.author: IY
reviews.title: Lesson time flies quickly
reviews.comment_content:
Introduction to sustainability as the name suggests. Quite many slides in each powerpoint but easy to understand because some are just common sense. You need to understand the key concepts and explain them in your own words in midterm exam (but I don't think they expect you to recite every single technical term).

Also, there is only one midterm exam (which covers part A of the course) and no final. So you don't actually need to care much about part B.

PART A
Introduction
Anthropogenic (human) impact on natural systems
Planetary boundaries and Earth systems
Human thriving within planetary boundaries
Policy approaches for sustainability
Sustainable development and sustainable communities

PART B
Energy futures
Futures for fresh water
Urban futures
Sustainable consumption and design for a circular economy
Futures thinking

By the way, there is a group project in which we have to design a poster on the topic of sustainability in a group of 6 (with groupmates from different years and different schools). Many groups will put much content on the "poster" and make it like a infographic. The professor will probably show you some good samples as reference though.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Quite interesting. There are many class activities so although each lesson lasts for 3 hours, you don't feel bored. Part A of the course was taught by my own professor (i.e. Prof Lu). Part B was taught by instructors from other sessions.

Prof. LU has a pretty strong mainland accent. However, I think it is still easy to understand what he says. He doesn't speak too fast and is quite encouraging. He wants students to participate in class but he won't force you to do so.

Other instructors are also nice and present their materials clearly.
reviews.comment_grading: I didn't pay much effort in this course and managed to get a B+ so it's fair grading for me. Many people say you need to answer a lot of questions in class. I only answered one question throughout the whole semester but still got a good mark in participation. Midterm consisted of long questions. A bit like LS and you need to apply the concepts in real life. Group project is the most important component in this course so make sure you do it seriously.
reviews.comment_workload:
- Take attendance
- One midterm but no final
- A group project (need presentation)
- A reflection essay (800 words)
- One 3-hour lesson each week
- One to two class activities per lesson
- No quiz
- Required reading PPT slides (supposedly) to be read before each lesson (~70 slides usually)

reviews.author: aspatel
reviews.comment_content:
Content is quite broad and as a result you don't get a lot of detail into each aspect however, it is quite interesting ad optional reading materials are provided. Topics include:
- anthropogenic impact
- planetary boundaries
- human thriving
- policy
- sustainable development
- energy
- water
- urban features
- sustainable consumption
reviews.comment_teaching: The teacher is very friendly and the classes are quite interactive. Most of the lectures are discussions and every week there is also an in-class activity. Although the lectures are long, time passes quickly because the content is interesting.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is extremely fair. The midterm consists of short essay questions and the professor is willing to negotiate and accept any reasonable response. for the midterm, make sure you remember a case study for the main topics as it will help boost your grade a lot.
Group Project: 40%
Individual Reflection essay: 15%
Participation: 15%
Midterm:  30%
In the end I got an A- even without much participation. Just make sure you attend every class so the professor remembers you.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is extremely light and I think this class is an easy A. The slides for each class are released 24 hours in advance and you are supposed to read through them before attending so you have enough knowledge to participate in class, however I only did this once throughout the whole semester and was fine. Most of it is common sense so you can get away with just sharing your own opinions. Apart from that the only other work you have is the group project which is a poster you need to make. It doesn't take very long as you are given class time to work on it as well.

reviews.author: Stevekc
reviews.comment_content: This course introduces students to the full scope of the issues related to the sustainability of humanity on a planet with limited natural and social capacities. The principal contributions of science, engineering, business management, the social sciences and humanities to understanding and resolving these issues will be reviewed, providing students with a gateway to further studies in sustainability.
reviews.comment_teaching: Lectures tend to focus on theories as opposed to solving questions. I suggest attending all tutorial lessons as they provide useful resources and teach you how to answer exam style questions.

reviews.author: Kennith
reviews.title: Weird Course
reviews.comment_content:
introduction to sustainability
-basic topics and basically common sense knowledge, you can hardly find new/ difficult concepts, simply common sense explained in details and sustainability terms.
-Anthropogenic (human) impact on natural systems
-Planetary boundaries and Earth systems
-Human thriving within planetary boundaries
-Policy approaches for sustainability  
-Sustainable development and sustainable
communities
-Energy futures  
-Futures for freshwater  
-Design for a circular economy  
-Sustainable consumption
-Futures thinking
reviews.comment_teaching:
-discussion and activities are prepared every lecture.
-lot's of videos and clips, it is quite boring using zoom but I guess it should be better with face-to-face teaching mode.
reviews.comment_grading:
Mid-term Exam (30%)
Mini quizzes (15%)
Group project (35%)
Written Essay (10%)
Class attendance and participation (10%)
reviews.comment_workload: normal workload as you'll need to read pre-lecture materials every week, finish 5 mini-quizzes (5mcqs each), and 2 group projects and a written essay

reviews.author: exwarty
reviews.comment_content:
1. Introduction
2. Anthropogenic impact on natural systems
3. Planetary boundaries and Earth systems
4. Human thriving within planetary boundaries
5. Policy approaches for sustainability

Midterm

6. Sustainable development and sustainable communities
7. Energy futures
8. Futures for fresh water
9. Design for a circular economy
10. Sustainable consumption
11. Futures thinking

Overall content was broad but relatively easy to understand
reviews.comment_teaching:
As there's only one lesson per week, the lecture is around 3 hrs long. It can get quite boring really quickly, but there are 2 breaks during class (at least for online courses)

It feels like the professor kind of knows what he's talking about, but I feel like most of the time he's just reading off his own notes, which is fine but again, it can get quite boring at times when you can just read lecture notes yourself.

TAs are only there when you are divided into breakout rooms and they monitor you to make sure that you have your cameras on for marks
reviews.comment_grading:
30% midterm
35% group project (2 interim reports 15%, poster 15%, peer evaluation 5%)
15% mini quizzes (best 3 of 5)
10% reflection paper


Only way to get good grade is probably by getting good groupmates for worksheet and midterm
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload was okay, there were some prior reading that was required before class. The quizzes were based on those readings, so if you want to get good grades then do those readings. It takes around 5 mins to go through the entire quiz anyways.

Make sure you have good groupmates, or else it's going to be very difficult on you. I had 2 freeriders who did basically nothing during discussions and barely helped out with group project

reviews.author: wendyliang22
reviews.comment_content:
The content was good and it made me genuinely care about sustainability! Professor Lu goes into detail about the different contributors to climate change, and provides both (1) scientific and (2) sociological/business related insight on why and how climate change occurs.

The part of the course which I enjoyed the most was the solutions oriented focus. Professor Zhongming spends a lot of time prompting students to consider not justhow and why climate change occurs, but what could be done to mitigate it.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The teaching was in general quite good. Professor Zhongming has an accent but his english is clear and understandable. The professor also tries to integrate a number of activities into the lessons to make it more interesting despite the lesson times being three hours long.

The only suggestion is that sometimes the activities may be a bit confusing, and especially when students are grouped into random breakout rooms - they may not know what to do.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading was quite good. As long as you read over the class materials, and make sure to understand the concepts clearly (they are not too hard).
reviews.comment_workload: Workload in general was quite light but there are readings to do every week and mini quizes based off the readings.

reviews.author: lolidek
reviews.title: Good Course, Good Grade
reviews.comment_content:
The course-content was quite straightforward. The professor taught us about different sustainability concepts, namely:

Part A (Before Midterm):
1. Anthropogenic (human) impact on natural systems
2. Planetary boundaries and Earth systems
3. Human thriving within planetary boundaries
4. Policy approaches for sustainability
5. Sustainable development and sustainable communities

Part B (After Midterm):
6. Energy futures
7. Futures for fresh water
8. Design for a circular economy
9. Sustainable consumption
10. Futures thinking

It was nice because only the first half of the syllabus was actually tested through an exam, whilst we could get a bit creative about the second half by displaying our knowledge through a group poster presentation.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Zhongming was a very good professor in my opinion. Despite it having a 3 hour lecture every week, SUST1000 was an entertaining course as we had group activities every lecture. This lowered chances of us getting distracted.

These group activities also helped illustrate the different concepts being taught in class, which made them very helpful sources of information when answering exam questions in the midterm, or even in the poster presentation.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading was very good.

My Statistics:
(Group) Interim Report #1: 4.63/5 (Mean: 4.5)
(Group) Interim Report #2: 3.93/5 (Mean: 3.8)
Midterm: 33.5/35 (Mean: 27.9)
Mini-quizzes (Best 3/5): 15/15
Group Presentation: 9.3/10 (Mean: 7.9)
Group Project Peer Review: 5/5 (Mean: 4.3)
Reflection Paper: 12/15 (Mean: 11.5)
Participation: Not Provided

I ended up getting an A+ at the end, even though I was only expecting to get an A- at best, as my reflection paper as well as the interim reports were only slightly above mean. Zhongming was also willing to answer questions regarding grading, and was very prompt in his replies, which made the grade review process very smooth.
reviews.comment_workload:
Despite not being overwhelming, the workload was definitely not light. There were many components which required us to spend a-lot of time working together as a group.

Furthermore, although it didn't look like much at the start, there were actually a-lot of readings that had to be done prior to the midterm exam. Nevertheless, it is easy to make stuff up during the exam when giving arguments (as long as they make logical sense).

Overall it was a great course, one that I enjoyed a-lot more than I thought I would!

reviews.author: therock
reviews.title: Somewhat Easy A
reviews.comment_content: Standard sustainability topics, if you know anything about climate change and other environmental issues already, this class will just kinda review them using real world examples. A little bit on political/social/economic sustainability, but mostly environmental. If you don't care about the environment don't join this class!
reviews.comment_teaching: I liked our prof, Norman, and at one point we had a couple other specialist profs visit and teach a couple lectures which was a nice variety. The only downside is the class duration, even with the break in the middle the class feels wayyyy too long and half the students are falling asleep in the second half of class.
reviews.comment_grading: Best grading from any class I've taken at UST so far! I got an A and didn't put an insane amount of work into it. The two main things that will determine your grade are the midterm and final project so work hard on those.
reviews.comment_workload: Not too heavy, I probably spent the least amount of time on this course from all my classes. The final project was less work than my project for a 2 credit mgmt course. No homework assignments, only have to study a bit for the midterm (I started about 5 days before and studied around 2 hours a day). Group work is spread out evenly enough if you're lucky with your group members so you don't have too much to worry about there either.
